{{primary sources|date=January 2016}} [[File:Space Engineers 5.jpg|thumb|''Space Engineers'' video game: 3D spatial navigation]] '''Spatial ability''' or visuo-spatial ability is the capacity to understand, reason and remember the spatial relations among objects or space.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://web.jhu.edu/cty/STBguide.pdf|title = Spatial ability|date = |accessdate = |website = www.jhu.edu|publisher = Johns Hopkins University|last = |first = }}</ref>
Visual-spatial abilities are used for everyday use from navigation, understanding or fixing equipment, understanding or estimating distance and measurement, and performing on a job. Spatial abilities are also important for success in fields such as sports, technical aptitude, [[mathematics]], natural sciences, [[engineering]], economic forecasting, [[meteorology]], [[chemistry]] and [[physics]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url = http://web.jhu.edu/cty/STBguide.pdf|title = What is spatial ability?|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = Johns Hopkins University|author = Johns Hopkins University}}</ref><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|title = Women in Science and Mathematics|url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK23762/|date = 2006-01-01|first = National Academy of Sciences|last = (us)|first2 = National Academy of Engineering|last2 = (us)|first3 = and Institute of Medicine (US) Committee on Maximizing the Potential of Women in Academic Science and|last3 = Engineering}}</ref> Not only do spatial abilities involve understanding the outside world, but they also involve processing outside information and reasoning with it through visual representation in the mind.
== Definition and types == Spatial ability is the capacity to understand, reason and remember the spatial relations among objects or space.<ref name=":0" /> There are four common types of spatial abilities which include spatial or visuo-spatial perception, spatial visualization, mental folding and [[mental rotation]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Impact of cognitive imaging and sex differences on the development of laparoscopic suturing skills|journal = Canadian Journal of Surgery|date = 2005-10-01|issn = 0008-428X|pmc = 3211902|pmid = 16248138|pages = 387–393|volume = 48|issue = 5|first = Tyrone|last = Donnon|first2 = Jean-Gaston|last2 = DesCôteaux|first3 = Claudio|last3 = Violato}}</ref> Each of these abilities have unique properties and importance to many types of tasks whether in certain jobs or everyday life. For example, spatial perception is defined as the ability to perceive spatial relationships in respect to the orientation of one's body despite distracting information.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|title = Emergence and Characterization of Sex Differences in Spatial Ability: A Meta-Analysis|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/19086027_Emergence_and_Characterization_of_Sex_Differences_in_Spatial_Ability_A_Meta-Analysis|journal = Child Development|pages = 1479–1498|volume = 56|issue = 6|doi = 10.1111/j.1467-8624.1985.tb00213.x|first = Marcia C.|last = Linn|first2 = Anne C.|last2 = Petersen}}</ref> [[mental rotation]] on the other hand is the mental ability to manipulate and rotate 2D or 3D objects in space quickly and accurately.<ref name=":1" /> Lastly, spatial visualization is characterized as complicated multi-step manipulations of spatially presented information.<ref name=":11" /> These three abilities are mediated and supported by a fourth spatial cognitive factor known as spatial working memory. [[Spatial memory|Spatial working memory]] is the ability to temporarily store a certain amount of visual-spatial memories under attentional control in order to complete a task.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|title = A Comparison of Laboratory and Clinical Working Memory Tests and Their Prediction of Fluid Intelligence|journal = Intelligence|date = 2009-05-01|issn = 0160-2896|pmc = 2818304|pmid = 20161647|pages = 283|volume = 37|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/j.intell.2008.11.005|first = Jill T.|last = Shelton|first2 = Emily M.|last2 = Elliott|first3 = B. D.|last3 = Hill|first4 = Matthew R.|last4 = Calamia|first5 = Wm. Drew|last5 = Gouvier}}</ref> This cognitive ability mediates individual differences in the capacity for higher level spatial abilities such as mental rotation.
=== Spatial perception === [[File:Видеоскриншот из игры S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Mobile.gif|thumb|Action shooting game: Use of spatial perceptual skills]] Spatial perception is defined as the ability to perceive spatial relationships in respect to the orientation of one's body despite distracting information.<ref name=":1" /> It consists of being able to perceive and visually understand outside spatial information such as features, properties, measurement, shapes, position and motion.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://www.people.fas.harvard.edu/~asimmons/pdfs/PT%20Spatial%20Perception.pdf|title = Spatial Perception from a Cartesian Point of View|last = Simmons|first = Alison|date = 2003|journal = Philosophical Topics |volume=31|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> For example, when one is navigating through a dense forest they are using spatial perception and awareness. Another example is when trying to understand the relations and mechanics inside of a car, he or she is relying on their spatial perception to understand its visual framework. Tests that measure spatial perception include the [[rod and frame test]], where subjects must place a rod vertically while viewing a frame orientation of 22 degrees in angle, or the [[water-level task]], where subjects have to draw or identify a horizontal line in a tilted bottle.<ref name=":11" />
Spatial perception is also very relevant in sports. For example, a study found that [[cricket]] players who were faster at picking up information from briefly presented visual displays were significantly better batsmen in an actual game.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Inspection time and high-speed ball games|journal = Perception|date = 1989-01-01|issn = 0301-0066|pmid = 2628929|pages = 789–792|volume = 18|issue = 6|first = I. J.|last = Deary|first2 = H.|last2 = Mitchell|doi=10.1068/p180789}}</ref> A 2015 study published in the ''[[Journal of Vision]]'' found that soccer players had higher perceptual ability for body kinematics such as processing multitasking crowd scenes which involve pedestrians crossing a street or complex dynamic visual scenes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Assessment of sport specific and non-specific biological motion perception in soccer athletes shows a fundamental perceptual ability advantage over non-athletes for recognizing body kinematics|journal = Journal of Vision|date = 2015-09-01|issn = 1534-7362|pmid = <!--none-->|pages = 504|volume = 15|issue = 12|doi = 10.1167/15.12.504|first = Thomas|last = Romeas|first2 = Jocelyn|last2 = Faubert}}</ref> Another study published in the ''Journal of Human Kinetics'' on fencing athletes found that achievement level was highly correlated with spatial perceptual skills such as visual discrimination, visual-spatial relationships, visual sequential memory, narrow attentional focus and visual information processing.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Attention, Visual Perception and their Relationship to Sport Performance in Fencing|journal = Journal of Human Kinetics|date = 2013-12-31|issn = 1640-5544|pmc = 3916930|pmid = 24511355|pages = 195–201|volume = 39|doi = 10.2478/hukin-2013-0082|first = Mona Mohamed Kamal|last = Hijazi}}</ref> A review published in the journal of ''[[Neuropsychologia]]'' found that spatial perception involves attributing meaning to an object or space, so that their sensory processing is actually part of semantic processing of the incoming visual information.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = Visual cognition: a new look at the two-visual systems model|journal = Neuropsychologia|date = 2005-01-01|issn = 0028-3932|pmid = 15707914|pages = 301–312|volume = 43|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2004.11.016|first = M.|last = Jeannerod|first2 = P.|last2 = Jacob}}</ref> The review also found that spatial perception involves the [[Visual system|human visual system]] in the brain and the [[Parietal lobe|parietal lobule]] which is responsible for visuomotor processing and visually goal-directed action.<ref name=":2" /> Studies have also found that individuals who played first person shooting games had better spatial perceptual skills like faster and more accurate performance in a peripheral and identification task while simultaneously performing a central search.<ref name="Wu 673–686">{{Cite journal|title = Playing shooter and driving videogames improves top-down guidance in visual search|journal = Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics|date = 2013-05-01|issn = 1943-393X|pmid = 23460295|pages = 673–686|volume = 75|issue = 4|doi = 10.3758/s13414-013-0440-2|first = Sijing|last = Wu|first2 = Ian|last2 = Spence}}</ref> Researchers suggested that, in addition to enhancing the ability to divide attention, playing action games significantly enhances perceptual skills like top-down guidance of attention to possible target locations.<ref name="Wu 673–686" />
=== Mental rotation === [[File:Rubik's cube 2.svg|thumb|[[Rubik's cube]]: a popular puzzle that involves 3D mental rotation]][[Mental rotation]] is the ability to mentally represent and ''rotate'' 2D and 3D objects in space quickly and accurately, while the object's features remain unchanged. Mental representations of physical objects can help utilize problem solving and understanding. For example, Hegarty (2004) showed that people manipulate mental representations for reasoning about mechanical problems, such as how gears or pulleys work.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Online Psychology Laboratory - About Mental Rotation|url = http://opl.apa.org/Experiments/About/AboutMentalRotation.aspx|website = opl.apa.org|accessdate = 2016-01-09}}</ref> Similarly, Schwartz and Black (1999) found that doing such mental simulations such as pouring water improves people's skill to find the solution to questions about the amount of tilt required for containers of different heights and widths.<ref name=":3" /> In the field of sports psychology, coaches for a variety of sports (e.g. basketball, gymnastics, soccer or golf) have promoted players to use mental imagery and manipulation as one technique for performance in their game. (Jones & Stuth, 1997)<ref name=":3" /> Recent research (e.g., Cherney, 2008) has also demonstrated evidence that playing video games with consistent practice can improve mental rotation skills, for example improvements in women's scores after practice with a game that involved a race within a 3-D environment.<ref name=":3" /> Same effects have been seen playing action video games such as [[Unreal Tournament]] as well as the popular mainstream game [[Tetris]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The virtual brain: 30 years of video-game play and cognitive abilities|journal = Frontiers in Psychology|date = 2013-09-13|issn = 1664-1078|pmc = 3772618|pmid = 24062712|volume = 4|doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00629|first = Andrew J.|last = Latham|first2 = Lucy L. M.|last2 = Patston|first3 = Lynette J.|last3 = Tippett}}</ref> [[Jigsaw puzzle|Jigsaw]] puzzles and [[Rubik's Cube|Rubik's cube]] are also activities that involve higher level of mental rotation and can be practiced to improve spatial abilities over time.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Early Puzzle Play: A predictor of preschoolers’ spatial transformation skill|journal = Developmental Psychology|date = 2012-03-01|issn = 0012-1649|pmc = 3289766|pmid = 22040312|pages = 530–542|volume = 48|issue = 2|doi = 10.1037/a0025913|first = S.C.|last = Levine|first2 = K.R.|last2 = Ratliff|first3 = J.|last3 = Huttenlocher|first4 = J.|last4 = Cannon}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Talent in autism: hyper-systemizing, hyper-attention to detail and sensory hypersensitivity|journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences|date = 2009-05-27|issn = 0962-8436|pmc = 2677592|pmid = 19528020|pages = 1377–1383|volume = 364|issue = 1522|doi = 10.1098/rstb.2008.0337|first = Simon|last = Baron-Cohen|first2 = Emma|last2 = Ashwin|first3 = Chris|last3 = Ashwin|first4 = Teresa|last4 = Tavassoli|first5 = Bhismadev|last5 = Chakrabarti}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Adolescence: The Transitional Years|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sz20BQAAQBAJ|publisher = Academic Press|date = 2014-05-10|isbn = 9781483265650|first = J. Roy|last = Hopkins}}</ref>
Mental rotation is also unique and distinct from the other spatial abilities because it also involves areas associated with [[Motor skill|motor simulation]] in the brain.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Neuroimaging studies of mental rotation: a meta-analysis and review|journal = Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date = 2008-01-01|issn = 0898-929X|pmid = 17919082|pages = 1–19|volume = 20|issue = 1|doi = 10.1162/jocn.2008.20013|first = Jeffrey M.|last = Zacks}}</ref>
=== Spatial visualization === Spatial visualization is characterized as complicated multi-step manipulations of spatially presented information.<ref name=":11" /> It involves [[Mental image|visual imagery]] which is the ability to mentally represent visual appearances of an object, and [[Mental image|spatial imagery]] which consists of mentally representing spatial relations between the parts or locations of the objects or movements.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|url = http://ideal-group.org/visualization-research/Spatial-Visualization-Visual-Imagery-and-Mathematical-Problem-Solving-of-Students-with-Varying-Abilities.pdf|title = Spatial Visualization, Visual Imagery, and Mathematical Problem Solving of Students With Varying Abilities|last = Van Garderen|first = Delinda|date = 2006|journal = JOURNAL OF LEARNING DISABILITIES VOLUME 39, NUMBER 6|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Spatial visualization is especially important in the domains of science and technology. For example, an astronomer must mentally visualize the structures of a solar system and the motions of the objects within it.<ref name=":4" /> An engineer mentally visualizes the interactions of the parts of a machine or building that he or she is assigned to design or work with.<ref name=":4" /> Chemists must be able to understand formulas which can be viewed as abstract models of molecules with most of the spatial information deleted; spatial skills are important in restoring that information when more detailed mental models of the molecules are needed in the formulas.<ref name=":4" />
Spatial visualization also involves imagining and working with visual details of measurement, shapes, motion, features and properties through mental imagery and using this spatial relations to derive at an understanding to a problem. Whereas spatial perception involves understanding externally via the senses, spatial visualization is the understanding internally through mental imagery in one's mind.
Another critical spatial visualization ability is '''mental animation'''.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|title = Mental animation in the visuospatial sketchpad: evidence from dual-task studies|journal = Memory & Cognition|date = 1997-05-01|issn = 0090-502X|pmid = 9184484|pages = 321–332|volume = 25|issue = 3|first = V. K.|last = Sims|first2 = M.|last2 = Hegarty|doi=10.3758/bf03211288}}</ref> Mental animation is mentally visualizing the motion and movement of components within any form of system or in general.<ref name=":9" /> It is an ability highly crucial in mechanical reasoning and understanding, for example mental animation in mechanical tasks can involve deconstructing a pulley system mentally into smaller units and animating them in the corresponding sequence or laws in the mechanical system.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Mental animation: inferring motion from static displays of mechanical systems|journal = Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|date = 1992-09-01|issn = 0278-7393|pmid = 1402712|pages = 1084–1102|volume = 18|issue = 5|first = M.|last = Hegarty|doi=10.1037/0278-7393.18.5.1084}}</ref> In short, mental animation is mental imagining how mechanical objects work by analyzing the motion of their smaller parts.
'''Mental folding''' is a complex spatial visualization that involves the ''folding'' of 2D pattern or material into 3D objects and representations.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|title = Mental Paper Folding Performance Following Penetrating Traumatic Brain Injury in Combat Veterans: A Lesion Mapping Study|journal = Cerebral Cortex (New York, NY)|date = 2013-07-01|issn = 1047-3211|pmc = 3673178|pmid = 22669970|pages = 1663–1672|volume = 23|issue = 7|doi = 10.1093/cercor/bhs153|first = Leila|last = Glass|first2 = Frank|last2 = Krueger|first3 = Jeffrey|last3 = Solomon|first4 = Vanessa|last4 = Raymont|first5 = Jordan|last5 = Grafman}}</ref> Compared to other studies, mental folding has had relatively little research and study. In comparison to mental rotation, mental folding is a non-rigid spatial transformation ability which means features of the manipulated object end up changing unlike mental rotation. In rigid manipulations, the object itself is not changed but rather its spatial position or orientation is, whereas in non-rigid transformations like mental folding the object and shapes are changed.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Understanding spatial transformations: similarities and differences between mental rotation and mental folding|journal = Cognitive Processing|date = 2013-05-01|issn = 1612-4790|pmid = 23397105|pages = 105–115|volume = 14|issue = 2|doi = 10.1007/s10339-013-0544-6|first = Justin|last = Harris|first2 = Kathy|last2 = Hirsh-Pasek|first3 = Nora S.|last3 = Newcombe}}</ref> Mental folding in tasks usually require a series of mental rotations to sequentially fold the object into a new one. Classic mental folding tests are the Paper folding task which is similar to [[Origami]]. Origami also requires mental folding by assessing folding a 2D paper enough times to create a 3D figure.<ref name=":10"/>
'''Visual penetrative ability''' is least common spatial visualization task which involves ability to imagine what is inside an object based on the features outside.<ref name=":12" />
== Spatial working memory == [[Spatial memory|Spatial working memory]] is the ability to temporarily store visual-spatial memories under [[attentional control]], in order to complete a task.<ref name=":8" /> This cognitive ability mediates individual differences in the capacity for higher level spatial abilities, such as mental rotation. Spatial working memory involves storing large amounts of short-term spatial memories in relation to visuo-spatial sketchpad. It is used in the temporary storage and manipulation of visual-spatial information such as memorizing shapes, colours, location or motion of objects in space. It is also involved in tasks which consist of planning of spatial movements, like planning one's route through a complex building. The visuospatial sketchpad can be split into separate visual, spatial and possibly kin-aesthetic (movement) components. Its neurobiological function also correlates within the right [[Cerebral hemisphere|hemisphere]] of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal |doi = 10.1016/S1364-6613(00)01538-2|last1 = Baddeley|first1 = A.D.|year = 2000|title = The episodic buffer: A new component of working memory?|url = |journal = Trends in Cognitive Sciences|volume = 4|issue = 11|pages = 417–423|pmid = 11058819}}</ref>
== Vocational applications == Researchers have found that spatial ability plays an important role in advanced educational credentials in the science, technology, engineering or math (STEM).<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|url = https://my.vanderbilt.edu/smpy/files/2013/02/Wai2009SpatialAbility.pdf|title = Spatial Ability for STEM Domains: Aligning Over 50 Years of cumulative psychological Knowledge solidifies Its importance|last = Wai|first = Jonathan|date = 2009|journal = Journal of Educational Psychology|doi = 10.1037/a0016127|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Why do spatial abilities predict mathematical performance?|journal = Developmental Science|date = 2014-05-01|issn = 1363-755X|pmc = 3997754|pmid = 24410830|pages = 462–470|volume = 17|issue = 3|doi = 10.1111/desc.12138|first = Maria Grazia|last = Tosto|first2 = Ken B.|last2 = Hanscombe|first3 = Claire M.A.|last3 = Haworth|first4 = Oliver S.P.|last4 = Davis|first5 = Stephen A.|last5 = Petrill|first6 = Philip S.|last6 = Dale|first7 = Sergey|last7 = Malykh|first8 = Robert|last8 = Plomin|first9 = Yulia|last9 = Kovas}}</ref> From studies, it has been indicated that the probability of getting an advanced degree in STEM increases in positive relation to the level of one's spatial ability. For example, a 2009 study published in the [[Journal of Educational Psychology]] found that 45% of those with [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] PhDs were within top percentage of high spatial ability in a group of 400,000 participants who were analyzed for 11 years since they were in the 12th grade.<ref name=":5" /> Only less than 10% of those with [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] PhDs were below the top quarter in spatial ability during adolescence.<ref name=":5" /> The researchers then concluded how important spatial ability is for [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics|STEM]] and as a factor in achieving advanced educational success in that field.<ref name=":5" />
Spatial visualization is especially important in [[science]] and [[technology]]. For example, an [[astronomer]] must visually imagine the structures of a solar system, and the path of the bodies within it.<ref name=":4" /> An engineer must visually imagine the motions of the parts of a machine or building that he or she is assigned to work with.<ref name=":4" /> Chemists must be able to understand formulas which are essentially abstract models supposed to represent spatial dynamics of molecules, and thus spatial skills are important in visualizing the molecule models that are needed in the formulas.<ref name=":4" /> Spatial manipulation ability is also important in the field of structural geology, when visually imagining how rocks change through time, such as migration of a magma body through crust or progressive folding of a strati-graphic succession. Another spatial visualization skill known as ''visual penetrative ability'' is important in geology as it requires geologists to visualize what is inside of a solid object based on past knowledge.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|url = http://nagt-jge.org/doi/pdf/10.5408/1.3559671|title = Characterizing and Improving Spatial Visualization Skills|last = Titus|first = Sarah|date = 2009|journal = Journal of Geoscience Education|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Current literature also indicates that mathematics involves visuo-spatial processing. Studies have found that gifted students in math, for instance, perform better in spatial visualization than non-gifted students.<ref name=":6" /> A 2008 review published in the journal of ''Neuroscience Biobehavioural Reviews'' found evidence that visuo-spatial processing is intuitively involved in many aspects of processing numbers and calculating in math. For example, meaning of a digit in a multi-digit number is coded following spatial information given its relation to its position within the number.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Visualizing numbers in the mind's eye: the role of visuo-spatial processes in numerical abilities|journal = Neuroscience and Biobehavioral Reviews|date = 2008-10-01|issn = 0149-7634|pmid = 18584868|pages = 1361–1372|volume = 32|issue = 8|doi = 10.1016/j.neubiorev.2008.05.015|first = Maria Dolores|last = de Hevia|first2 = Giuseppe|last2 = Vallar|first3 = Luisa|last3 = Girelli}}</ref> Another study found that numerical estimation might rely on integrating different visual-spatial cues (diameter, size, location, measurement) to infer an answer.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The role of visual information in numerosity estimation|journal = PLOS ONE|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 1932-6203|pmc = 3355123|pmid = 22616007|pages = e37426|volume = 7|issue = 5|doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0037426|first = Titia|last = Gebuis|first2 = Bert|last2 = Reynvoet}}</ref> A study published in 2014 also found evidence that mathematical calculation relies on the integration of various spatial processes.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Doing arithmetic by hand: hand movements during exact arithmetic reveal systematic, dynamic spatial processing|journal = [[Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology]]|date = 2014-01-01|issn = 1747-0226|pmid = 25051274|pages = 1579–1596|volume = 67|issue = 8|doi = 10.1080/17470218.2014.897359|first = Tyler|last = Marghetis|first2 = Rafael|last2 = Núñez|first3 = Benjamin K.|last3 = Bergen}}</ref> Another 2015 study published in the journal of ''[[Frontiers in Psychology]]'' also found that numerical processing and arithmetic performance may rely on visual perceptual ability.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Visual perception can account for the close relation between numerosity processing and computational fluency|journal = Frontiers in Psychology|date = 2015-01-01|issn = 1664-1078|pmc = 4563146|pmid = 26441740|pages = 1364|volume = 6|doi = 10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01364|first = Xinlin|last = Zhou|first2 = Wei|last2 = Wei|first3 = Yiyun|last3 = Zhang|first4 = Jiaxin|last4 = Cui|first5 = Chuansheng|last5 = Chen}}</ref>
A 2007 study published in the journal of [[Cognitive science|''Cognitive Science'']] also found that spatial visualization ability is crucial for solving [[Kinematics|kinematic]] problems in physics. Nonetheless, current literature indicates that spatial abilities specifically mental rotation, is crucial for achieving success in various fields of chemistry, engineering and physics.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = Spatial Ability in Learning Engineering Mechanics: Critical Review|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/282853648_Spatial_Ability_in_Learning_Engineering_Mechanics_Critical_Review|website = ResearchGate|access-date = 2016-01-15|doi = 10.1061/(ASCE)EI.1943-5541.0000266}}</ref>

[[File:Fred Thompson in spin room.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Former U.S. Senator and debate participant [[Fred Thompson]] addresses reporters in the spin room following a [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2008#December 9.2C 2007 - Miami.2C Florida|Republican presidential primary debate]] in 2007.]]
A '''spin room''', also known as '''spin row'''<ref>{{cite web|last=Reaves|first=Jessica|title=As the Spin Room Turns|url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,56609,00.html|work=Time|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=4 October 2000}}</ref> or '''spin alley''',<ref>{{cite news|last=Mathes|first=Michael|title=Spin Alley: getting out the message over debate din|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i-iFl3wU6MNVZvub-ufTpJcw7jig|accessdate=23 October 2012|newspaper=Agence France-Presse|date=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="TribCritic">{{cite web|last=Rosenthal|first=Phil|title=Spin room coverage out of control|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2008-09-26/business/0809250750_1_post-debate-spin-operatives|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=26 September 2008}}</ref> is an area in which [[reporter]]s can speak with [[debate]] participants and/or their representatives after a debate. The name refers to the fact that the participants will attempt to "[[spin (public relations)|spin]]" or influence the perception of the debate among the assembled reporters. The benefit for reporters is that they quickly get in-person interviews with debaters or their representatives, complete with audio, video and photos. For a [[United States presidential election debates|U.S. presidential debate]], the number of reporters in the spin room can number into the thousands.<ref name="TwitterSpin">{{cite web|last=Calderone|first=Michael|title=For 2012 Presidential Debates, Campaigns Speed Up The Spin|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/01/2012-presidential-debates-spin-room_n_1929185.html|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=2 October 2012|date=1 October 2012}}</ref>
==History== The earliest known spin room was set up by the [[political campaign|campaign]] of U.S. president [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1984. In a hotel banquet room, campaign officials spoke on the record with [[talking point]]s playing up their own candidate's debate performance and minimizing opponent [[Walter Mondale]]'s success, despite many observers believing Mondale had just won. This operation was dubbed the "spin patrol."<ref>{{cite news|last=Santini|first=Maureen|title='Spin patrol' spins out|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=toNGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2229,1288893|accessdate=18 October 2012|newspaper=The Evening News|date=13 October 1984|agency=The Associated Press|location=Newburgh-Beacon, New York}}</ref>
==Operation== A spin room may also be active before a debate.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Zeke|title=Before The Spin Room, Campaigns Pre-Wash The Press|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/zekejmiller/before-the-spin-room-campaigns-pre-wash-the-press|work=BuzzFeed|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=17 October 2012}}</ref> A common form of pre-debate spin is for each side to try to raise expectations for the opposing debater and lower expectations for their own team, a pursuit known as playing the [[expectations game]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=Leigh Ann|title=What's behind the debate expectations game?|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-250_162-57529085/whats-behind-the-debate-expectations-game/|work=CBS News|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=10 October 2012}}</ref>
==Criticism== Some observers have criticized the overt nature of the [[media manipulation]] in spin rooms, and the media's willing participation in it.<ref name="TribCritic"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Jay|title=Raze Spin Alley, That Strange Creation of the Press|url=http://archive.pressthink.org/2003/11/22/spin_alley.html|work=PressThink|accessdate=23 October 2012|date=22 November 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Lanson|first=Jerry|title=The spin room - oily engine of the political meat grinder|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2003/1212/p11s01-coop.htm|work=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=12 December 2003}}</ref> Defenders have said reporters know it's scripted and aren't persuaded by the spin, but rather, they use the talking points to analyze candidates' strategies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hardman|first1=Isabel|title=A (partial) defence of the spin room|url=http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/coffeehouse/2015/04/a-partial-defence-of-the-spin-room/|website=The Spectator|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=30 April 2015}}</ref> Spin rooms can occasionally include moments of candor, such as when presidential candidate [[Rick Perry]] admitted that he had "stepped in it" during a debate response that became known as his [[Rick Perry presidential campaign, 2012#November 2011: "Oops" moment and continued struggles|"oops" moment]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Perry in spin room explains flub: "I stepped in it" (with video)|url=http://blogs.star-telegram.com/politex/2011/11/perry-in-spin-room-explains-flub-i-stepped-in-it-with-video.html|website=PoliTex|accessdate=6 August 2015|date=9 November 2011}}</ref>
Spin rooms have also been portrayed as outdated in an era of instant online reaction from all quarters before a debate is even over.<ref name="TwitterSpin"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Gaudin|first=Sharon|title=Twitter becomes new debate spin room|url=http://www.computerworld.com/s/article/9232060/Twitter_becomes_new_debate_spin_room|work=Computer World|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=4 October 2012}}</ref> [[Focus group]]s and instant post-debate "snap [[opinion poll|polls]]" attempt to provide a more scientific method than spin rooms in determining who has won a debate.<ref>{{cite web|title=US presidential debate: Early polls give Barack Obama slender victory|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/uselection2008/presidentialdebates/3092194/US-presidential-debate-Early-polls-give-Barack-Obama-slender-victory.html|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=15 October 2015|date=27 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Clegg Beats Brown, Cameron in U.K. TV Debate, Polls Show|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-04-15/clegg-wins-top-mark-in-u-k-debate-polls-as-brown-cameron-stay-deadlocked.html|work=Bloomberg|accessdate=9 November 2012|date=16 April 2010}}</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=May 2014}}
A '''topological quantum computer''' is a theoretical [[quantum computer]] that employs two-dimensional [[quasiparticle]]s called [[anyon]]s, whose [[world line]]s pass around one another to form [[braid theory|braids]] in a three-dimensional [[spacetime]] (i.e., one temporal plus two spatial dimensions). These braids form the [[logic gate]]s that make up the computer. The advantage of a quantum computer based on quantum braids over using trapped quantum particles is that the former is much more stable. Small, cumulative perturbations can cause quantum states to [[quantum decoherence|decohere]] and introduce errors in the computation, but such small perturbations do not change the braids' [[braid theory|topological properties]]. This is like the effort required to cut a string and reattach the ends to form a different braid, as opposed to a ball (representing an ordinary quantum particle in four-dimensional spacetime) bumping into a wall. [[Alexei Kitaev]] proposed topological quantum computation in 1997. While the elements of a topological quantum computer originate in a purely mathematical realm, experiments in [[Fractional quantum Hall effect|fractional quantum Hall systems]] indicate these elements may be created in the real world using [[semiconductor]]s made of [[gallium arsenide]] at a temperature of near [[absolute zero]] and subjected to strong [[magnetic fields]].
==Introduction== [[Anyon]]s are quasiparticles in a two-dimensional space. Anyons are neither [[fermion]]s nor [[boson]]s, but like fermions, they cannot occupy the same state. Thus, the [[world lines]] of two anyons cannot intersect or merge, which allows their paths to form stable braids in space-time. Anyons can form from excitations in a cold, two-dimensional electron gas in a very strong magnetic field, and carry fractional units of magnetic flux. This phenomenon is called the [[fractional quantum Hall effect]]. In typical laboratory systems, the electron gas occupies a thin semiconducting layer sandwiched between layers of aluminium gallium arsenide.
When anyons are braided, the transformation of the quantum state of the system depends only on the topological class of the anyons' trajectories (which are classified according to the [[braid group]]). Therefore, the quantum information which is stored in the state of the system is impervious to small errors in the trajectories. In 2005, [[Sankar Das Sarma]], [[Michael Freedman]], and [[Chetan Nayak]] proposed a quantum Hall device which would realize a topological qubit. In a key development for topological quantum computers, in 2005 Vladimir J. Goldman, Fernando E. Camino, and Wei Zhou were said to have created the first experimental evidence for using fractional quantum Hall effect to create actual anyons, although others have suggested their results could be the product of phenomena not involving anyons. It should also be noted that [[non-abelian group|non-abelian]] anyons, a species required for topological quantum computers, have yet to be experimentally confirmed. Possible experimental evidence has been found,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Willet|first=R.L.|date=January 15, 2013|title=Magnetic field-tuned Aharonov–Bohm oscillations and evidence for non-Abelian anyons at ν = 5/2|arxiv=1301.2639|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.111.186401|pmid=|access-date=|bibcode=2013PhRvL.111r6401W}}</ref> but the conclusions remain contested.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.126807| title=Enhanced Bulk-Edge Coulomb Coupling in Fractional Fabry-Perot Interferometers|first1=Curt | last1=von Keyserling | first2=S. H. | last2=Simon | first3=Rosenow | last3=Bernd | bibcode=2015PhRvL.115l6807V | volume=115 | journal=Physical Review Letters|arxiv=1411.4654}}</ref>
==Topological vs. standard quantum computer==
Topological quantum computers are equivalent in computational power to other standard models of quantum computation, in particular to the [[quantum circuit]] model and to the [[quantum Turing machine]] model. That is, any of these models can efficiently simulate any of the others. Nonetheless, certain algorithms may be a more natural fit to the topological quantum computer model. For example, algorithms for evaluating the [[Jones polynomial]] were first developed in the topological model, and only later converted and extended in the standard quantum circuit model.
===Computations=== To live up to its name, a topological quantum computer must provide the unique computation properties promised by a conventional quantum computer design, which uses trapped quantum particles. Fortunately in 2002, [[Michael H. Freedman]], [[Alexei Kitaev]], [[Michael J. Larsen]], and Zhenghan Wang proved that a topological quantum computer can, in principle, perform any computation that a conventional quantum computer can do.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Freedman|first=Michael|last2=Kitaev|first2=Alexei|last3=Larsen|first3=Michael|last4=Wang|first4=Zhenghan|date=2003-01-01|title=Topological quantum computation|url=http://www.ams.org/bull/2003-40-01/S0273-0979-02-00964-3/|journal=Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society|volume=40|issue=1|pages=31–38|doi=10.1090/S0273-0979-02-00964-3|issn=0273-0979|arxiv=quant-ph/0101025}}</ref>
They found that a conventional quantum computer device, given an error-free operation of its logic circuits, will give a solution with an absolute level of accuracy, whereas a topological quantum computing device with flawless operation will give the solution with only a finite level of accuracy. However, any level of precision for the answer can be obtained by adding more braid twists (logic circuits) to the topological quantum computer, in a simple linear relationship. In other words, a reasonable increase in elements (braid twists) can achieve a high degree of accuracy in the answer. Actual computation [gates] are done by the edge states of a fractional quantum Hall effect. This makes models of one-dimensional anyons important. In one space dimension, anyons are defined algebraically.
=== Error correction and control ===
Even though quantum braids are inherently more stable than trapped quantum particles, there is still a need to control for error inducing thermal fluctuations, which produce random stray pairs of anyons which interfere with adjoining braids. Controlling these errors is simply a matter of separating the anyons to a distance where the rate of interfering strays drops to near zero. Simulating the dynamics of a topological quantum computer may be a promising method of implementing fault-tolerant quantum computation even with a standard quantum information processing scheme. Raussendorf, Harrington, and Goyal have studied one model, with promising simulation results.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Raussendorf|first=R.|last2=Harrington|first2=J.|last3=Goyal|first3=K.|date=2007-01-01|title=Topological fault-tolerance in cluster state quantum computation|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1367-2630/9/i=6/a=199|journal=New Journal of Physics|language=en|volume=9|issue=6|pages=199|doi=10.1088/1367-2630/9/6/199|issn=1367-2630|arxiv=quant-ph/0703143|bibcode=2007NJPh....9..199R}}</ref>
== Example: Computing with Fibonacci Anyons == One of the prominent examples in topological quantum computing is with a system of [[fibonacci anyons]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Trebst|first=Simon|date=2008|title=A Short Introduction to Fibonacci Anyon Models|url=http://stationq.cnsi.ucsb.edu/~wang/Publications/34.pdf|journal=Progress of Theoretical Physics Supplement No. 176|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> These anyons can be used to create generic gates for topological quantum computing. There are three main steps for creating a model: * Choose our basis and restrict our [[Hilbert space]] * Braid the anyons together * Fuse the anyons at the end, and detect how they fuse in order to read the output of the system.
=== State Preparation ===
Fibonacci Anyons are defined by three qualities: # They have a topological charge of <math>\tau</math>. In this discussion, we consider another charge — <math>1</math> — which is the ‘vacuum’ charge if anyons are annihilated with each-other. # Each of these anyons are their own antiparticle. <math>\tau = \tau^*</math> and <math>1 = 1^*</math>. # If brought close to each-other, they will ‘fuse’ together in a nontrivial fashion. Specifically, the ‘fusion’ rules are: ## <math>1 \otimes 1 = 1</math> ## <math>1 \otimes \tau = \tau \otimes 1 = \tau</math> ## <math>\tau \otimes \tau = 1 \oplus \tau</math> # Many of the properties of this system can be explained similarly to that of two spin 1/2 particles. Particularly, we use the same [[tensor product]] <math>\otimes</math> and [[direct sum]] <math>\oplus</math> operators. The last ‘fusion’ rule can be extended this to a system of three anyons:
:<math>\tau \otimes \tau \otimes \tau = \tau \otimes (1 \oplus \tau) = \tau \otimes 1 \oplus \tau \otimes \tau = \tau \oplus 1 \oplus \tau = 1 \oplus 2 \cdot \tau</math>
Thus, fusing three anyons will yield a final state of total charge <math>\tau</math> in 2 ways, or a charge of <math>1</math> in exactly one way. We use three states to define our basis.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Nayak|first=Chetan|date=2008|title=Non-Abelian Anyons and Topological Quantum Computation|arxiv=0707.1889|doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.80.1083|pmid=|access-date=|bibcode=2008RvMP...80.1083N}}</ref> However, because we wish to encode these three anyon states as superpositions of 0 and 1, we need to limit the basis to a two-dimensional Hilbert Space. Thus, we consider only two states with a total charge of <math>\tau</math>. This choice is purely phenomenological. In these states, we group the two leftmost anyons into a 'control group', and leave the rightmost as a 'non-computational anyon'. We classify a <math>|0\rangle</math> state as one where the control group has total 'fused' charge of <math>1</math>, and a state of <math>|1 \rangle</math> has a control group with a total 'fused' charge of <math>\tau</math>. For a more complete description, see Nayak.<ref name=":0" />
=== Gates ===
Following the ideas above, [[Adiabatic theorem|adiabatically]] braiding these anyons around each-other with result in a unitary transformation. These braid operators are a result of two subclasses of operators: * The F matrix * The R matrix The R matrix can be conceptually thought of as the topological phase that is imparted onto the anyons during the braid. As the anyons wind around each-other, they pick up some phase due to the [[Aharonov–Bohm effect|Aharonov-Bohm]] effect.
The F matrix is a result of the physical rotations of the anyons. As they braid between each-other, it is important to realize that the bottom two anyons—the control group—will still distinguish the state of the qubit. Thus, braiding the anyons will change which anyons are in the control group, and therefore change the basis. We evaluate the anyons by always fusing the control group (the bottom anyons) together first, so exchanging which anyons these are will rotate the system. Because these anyons are [[non-abelian group|non-abelian]], the order of the anyons (which ones are within the control group) will matter, and as such they will transform the system.
The complete braid operator can be derived as:
<math>B=F^{-1} R F</math>
In order to mathematically construct the F and R operators, we can consider permutations of these F and R operators. We know that if we sequentially change the basis that we are operating on, this will eventually lead us back to the same basis. Similarly, we know that if we braid anyons around each-other a certain number of times, this will lead back to the same state. These axioms are called the [[pentagon]]al and [[hexagonal axiom]]<nowiki/>s respectively as performing the operation can be visualized with a pentagon/hexagon of state transformations. Although mathematically difficult,<ref>Eric Paquette. Topological quantum computing with anyons, 1 2009. Categories, Logic and Foundations of Physics IV.</ref> these can be approached much more successfully visually.
With these braid operators, we can finally formalize the notion of braids in terms of how they act on our Hilbert space and construct arbitrary universal quantum gates.
Explicit braids that perform particular quantum computations with Fibonacci anyons have been given by <ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.140503|title=Braid Topologies for Quantum Computation | bibcode=2005PhRvL..95n0503B | volume=95|journal=Physical Review Letters|arxiv=quant-ph/0505065}}</ref>

The '''Venture Capital Investment Competition''' ('''VCIC''') is an entrepreneurial education program developed and coordinated by the University of North Carolina's [[Kenan-Flagler Business School]].
==History== VCIC began in the middle of the [[dot-com bubble]] in 1998 in response to the number of business plan competitions popping up at most [[business school]]s. VCIC has grown into a virtual venture [[job fair]] and marketplace. The program culminates every April in [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|Chapel Hill, North Carolina]], with the International Finals, where the winning teams take home $5,000 in prize money.
==Events in 2011== In 2011 the program included ten regional finals and 40 single-school events in North America, Europe and Asia. Fifty top business schools from around the world participated in the competition.
Events took place at the following dates and locations: *Mountain VCIC Region at [[University of Colorado at Boulder|University of Colorado]] February 11 *Silicon Valley VCIC Region at [[Santa Clara University]] February 11 *Southeast VCIC Region at [[Georgetown University]] February 4 *Mid-Atlantic VCIC Region at [[Carnegie Mellon]] February 18 *European VCIC Region at [[London Business School]] February 25 *Northeast VCIC Region at [[New York University]] February 25 *Asian VCIC Region at [[Indian School of Business]] February 26 *Southwest VCIC Region at [[University of Southern California]] March 4 *New England VCIC Region at Columbia Graduate School of Business March 4 *European VCIC Region at Oxford Said Business School March 4 *International VCIC Finals at [[University of North Carolina]] April 16–18
